Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>
>This sounds like a good idea.  I will keep it in mind.  You know, 
>ultimately what we are up against is just the fact that no sample 
>can be guaranteed to perfectly represent its generating distribution.
>It's likely there will always be extraordinary situations that were 
>not encountered in whatever training set was experienced during 
>evolution.  At the same time, that doesn't mean we can't do better, 
>it just means reaching exactly 100% of all possible test cases is 
>unlikely for complicated problems or domains.
>
>  
>
What has been surprising to me is how this problem has come up while 
evolving for relatively simple problems, e.g. with prey capture the 
difficulty level is increased by allowing the prey more 'head start' 
moves before the agent can move. At below 4 moves the prey should always 
remain within the agent's sensor range, thus a very simple solution is 
possible whereby sensors are directly connected to motor outputs. And 
yet the pass rate is still not 100% in all but the easiest problem, take 
a look at these success rates for champs at each difficultly level:

Initial moves   100 tests   1000 tests
-------------------------------------
0                     100%         100%
1                     96.48%      99.9%
2                     94.56%      99.9%
3                     95.10%      99.9%


Hopefully that table didn't get too mangled in transmission.

So there is a balance between the sample size (and therefore search 
speed) and solution quality, and for all but the most trivial problems 
this balance seems to follow the law of dimishing returns. Hopefuly by 
using a buffer of failed tests I can tip the balance more in our favour 
- better solutions without all of the cost of performing 1000 tests.

But yes I'm beginning to see that obtaining 100% perfect solutions for 
most problems is perhaps unrealistic, but a 99.9% sucess is a lot more 
useful that 95% - that could be the difference between a commercially 
viable technique (say fingerprint ID'ing) and one that isn't.

Colin
